newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corporate market off to a slow start.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corporate market off to a slow start.

text.p: Primary and secondary market activity among U.S. corporate bonds was subdued on the Monday following the Thanksgiving vacation, traders said.
Traders said prices on high-grade bonds were unchanged relative to Treasuries, while junk bonds ended the day unchanged to marginally higher.
Volume in both markets was low, they added.
TCI Communications Inc bonds tightened several basis points on Monday as the market digested news of a $500 million shelf offering of preferred stock by the company.
TCI said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last Wednesday that it would use proceeds from the offering to pay down existing commerical paper.
Some market players said the move could help the company avoid a downgrade of its debt rating, which is currently under review by Standard & Poor's.
But Marion Boucher Soper, a media analyst at Bear Stearns & Co Inc, said the move was unlikely to affect S&P's decision.
"This may help their balance sheet but there are bigger issues which S&P is dealing with, such as whether the company will hit its debt-to-cash flow projections," she said.
The S&P analyst covering TCI debt could not be reached for comment.
Among high-yield credits, bids for MobileMedia 9-3/8 percent bonds fell two to three points as the company failed to make interst payments by the end of a grace period.
In the primary market, while no investment-grade corporate deals priced on Monday, syndicate officials expected total new issuance for the week to come in at $4 billion to $5 billion.

One sydnicate official predicted new issuance would increase substantially from these levels if the yield on the on-the-run ten-year Treasury dropped below six percent or if the yield on the benchmark 30-year dropped below 6-1/4 percent.

"If the long bond dips below 6-1/4 that would allow a single-A issuer to finance inside seven percent and that's pretty attractive. You could see a slew of new bank and finance paper and a marginal pickup in industrial issuance at those rates."
The on-the-run ten-year closed at 103-7/32 to yield 6.06 percent. The benchmark long-bond closed at 101-27/32 to yield 6.36 percent.
Despite a heavy forward calendar of well over $1 billion in new high-yield deals, syndicate officials said new issuance could be light this week as many dealers were conducting roadshows.

In what may be an indication that investor appetite for new high-yield paper remains strong, AES China Generating Co increased the size of its upcoming junk deal to $180 million from $150 million, according to a source familiar with the situation.
The deal, which will be underwritten by Morgan Stanley & Co Inc, will be priced next week, the source said.
